description: From Middle English murder, murdre, mourdre, alteration of earlier murthre (‚Äúmurder‚Äù) (see murther), from Old English mor√æor (‚Äúsecret slaying, unlawful killing‚Äù) and Old English myr√æra (‚Äúmurder, homicide‚Äù), both from Proto-West Germanic *mor√ær, from Proto-Germanic *mur√ærƒÖ (‚Äúdeath, killing, murder‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *mrÃ•tro- (‚Äúkilling‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *mer-, *mor-, *mrÃ•- (‚Äúto die‚Äù).
Akin to Gothic êåºêå∞êåøêçÇêå∏êçÇ (maur√ær, ‚Äúmurder‚Äù), Old High German mord (‚Äúmurder‚Äù), Old Norse mor√∞ (‚Äúmurder‚Äù), Old English myr√ærian (‚Äúto murder‚Äù) and mor√æ.

The -d- in the Middle English form may have been influenced in part by Anglo-Norman murdre, from Old French murdre, from Medieval Latin murdrum (whence the English doublet of murdrum), from Frankish *mor√ær, *mur√ær (‚Äúmurder‚Äù), from the same Germanic root, though this may also have been wholly the result of internal development (compare burden, from burthen).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The crime of deliberately killing a person without moral justification.
(countable) The act of deliberate killing of a person or other being without moral justification, especially with malice aforethought.
(uncountable, used as a predicative noun) Something terrible to endure.
(countable, collective) A group of crows; the collective noun for crows.

definitionGroups.group: (uncountable) The crime of deliberately killing a person without moral justification.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, law, in jurisdictions which use the felony murder rule) The act of committing or abetting a serious crime that results in the killing of a person, regardless of intent; felony murder.
(countable) The act of deliberate killing of a person or other being without moral justification, especially with malice aforethought.
examples: There have been ten unsolved murders this year alone.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, used as a predicative noun) Something terrible to endure.
(countable, collective) A group of crows; the collective noun for crows.

verbs.description: murder (third-person singular simple present murders, present participle murdering, simple past and past participle murdered)

entries.meaning: To deliberately kill (a person or persons) without justification, especially with malice aforethought.
examples: The woman found dead in her kitchen was murdered by her husband.

entries.meaning: (transitive, sports, figuratively, colloquial, hyperbolic) To defeat decisively.
examples: Our team is going to murder them.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, colloquial, hyperbolic) To kick someone's ass or chew someone out (used to express one‚Äôs anger at somebody).
examples: He's torn my best shirt. When I see him, I'll murder him!
I could murder a hamburger right now.
